paragraphs.text:
%md
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://doc.splicemachine.com/zeppelin/css/zepstyles2.css" />

# Tuning for Performance

Tuning for performance is a critical topic for any database. This is especially true for Splice Machine, because its architecture may influence performance in ways unexpected by experienced database users.

Splice Machine uses a cost-based optimizer, which means that the database determines different plans (ways it can run) for a query. The optimizer estimates the *cost* of each possible plan, and chooses the lowest-cost option.

This Notebook introduces a number of tips you can employ to help generate the lowest cost plan and best performance for your queries, in these sections:

* *Collecting Statistics*
* *Performing Major Compactions*
* *Creating Primary Keys and Indexes*
* *Joining Tables*
* *Selecting a Join Strategy*

msg.data:
Tuning for Performance

Tuning for performance is a critical topic for any database. This is especially true for Splice Machine, because its architecture may influence performance in ways unexpected by experienced database users.

Splice Machine uses a cost-based optimizer, which means that the database determines different plans (ways it can run) for a query. The optimizer estimates the cost of each possible plan, and chooses the lowest-cost option.

This Notebook introduces a number of tips you can employ to help generate the lowest cost plan and best performance for your queries, in these sections:

  • Collecting Statistics
  • Performing Major Compactions
  • Creating Primary Keys and Indexes
  • Joining Tables
  • Selecting a Join Strategy

paragraphs.text: %md ## Collecting Statistics The first commands you should learn about are the statistics collection commands: * `ANALYZE TABLE` collects statistics for a specific table * `ANALYZE SCHEMA` collects statistics for all tables in a schema. Collecting statistics drastically improves the estimation of costs that the optimizer relies on to find the best plan. Let's take a look at the impact of running statistics on our import test table from *Importing Data* Notebook. You can most easily understand this by viewing the output from the `EXPLAIN` command. First, we'll click the *Run* button in the next paragraph to display the execution plan for our unoptimized query:

msg.data:
Collecting Statistics

The first commands you should learn about are the statistics collection commands:

  • ANALYZE TABLE collects statistics for a specific table
  • ANALYZE SCHEMA collects statistics for all tables in a schema.

Collecting statistics drastically improves the estimation of costs that the optimizer relies on to find the best plan.

Let’s take a look at the impact of running statistics on our import test table from Importing Data Notebook. You can most easily understand this by viewing the output from the EXPLAIN command. First, we’ll click the Run button in the next paragraph to display the execution plan for our unoptimized query:

paragraphs.text:
%splicemachine

explain select * from import_example a, import_example b
where a.i = 100

msg.data:
Plan
Cursor(n=5,rows=360,updateMode=READ_ONLY (1),engine=control)
  ->  ScrollInsensitive(n=4,totalCost=1744.96,outputRows=360,outputHeapSize=2.109 KB,partitions=1)
    ->  NestedLoopJoin(n=3,totalCost=1657.16,outputRows=360,outputHeapSize=2.109 KB,partitions=1)
      ->  TableScan[IMPORT_EXAMPLE(1616)](n=2,totalCost=4.04,scannedRows=20,outputRows=20,outputHeapSize=2.109 KB,partitions=1)
      ->  TableScan[IMPORT_EXAMPLE(1616)](n=1,totalCost=4.04,scannedRows=20,outputRows=18,outputHeapSize=54 B,partitions=1,preds=[(A.I[0:1] = 100)])

paragraphs.text:
%md
You'll notice, as you probably did when running the `explain` in the *Importing Data* tutorial, that the row counts are way off! That's because we have __not__ run statistics yet. When statistics have not been run, the optimizer makes an estimate, but row counts will be rough approximations. Let's collect some statistics by analyzing our table, and then we'll rerun the `explain`. When you click to run the next paragraph, you'll see that the row counts and costs are accurate.

Splice Machine recommends collecting statistics after initial loading of data into a table, and recollecting them if you've made significant changes to a table. Running the analyze command can take a bit of time, depending on the size of your database.

msg.data:
You’ll notice, as you probably did when running the explain in the Importing Data tutorial, that the row counts are way off! That’s because we have not run statistics yet. When statistics have not been run, the optimizer makes an estimate, but row counts will be rough approximations.

Let’s collect some statistics by analyzing our table, and then we’ll rerun the explain. When you click to run the next paragraph, you’ll see that the row counts and costs are accurate.

Splice Machine recommends collecting statistics after initial loading of data into a table, and recollecting them if you've made significant changes to a table. Running the analyze command can take a bit of time, depending on the size of your database.

paragraphs.text:
%splicemachine

analyze table import_example;

explain select * from import_example a, import_example b
where a.i = 100

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
schemaName	tableName	partition	rowsCollected	partitionSize	partitionCount	statsType	sampleFraction
SPLICE	IMPORT_EXAMPLE	-All-	4	108	1	2	0.0

Plan
Cursor(n=5,rows=4,updateMode=READ_ONLY (1),engine=control)
  ->  ScrollInsensitive(n=4,totalCost=48.172,outputRows=4,outputHeapSize=216 B,partitions=1)
    ->  NestedLoopJoin(n=3,totalCost=28.091,outputRows=4,outputHeapSize=216 B,partitions=1)
      ->  TableScan[IMPORT_EXAMPLE(1616)](n=2,totalCost=4.005,scannedRows=4,outputRows=4,outputHeapSize=216 B,partitions=1)
      ->  TableScan[IMPORT_EXAMPLE(1616)](n=1,totalCost=4.005,scannedRows=4,outputRows=1,outputHeapSize=27 B,partitions=1,preds=[(A.I[0:1] = 100)])

paragraphs.text:
%md ## Major Compactions Splice Machine stores its data in HBase HFiles. HBase is good at handling the creation of HFiles as needed; however, it's important to be aware that HBase does perform asynchronous maintenance tasks to keep HFile working as efficiently as possible: * HBase kicks off *Minor compactions* as a minor HFiles housekeeping task. * HBase triggers *Major compactions* less frequently; these do much more housekeeping. If you've just imported a lot of data (say 10M rows or so), it may be worth your while to manually trigger a major compaction using Splice Machine's `PERFORM_MAJOR_COMPACTION_ON_TABLE` command. Click to run the next paragraph, which triggers a major compaction of your `import_example` table.

Though major compactions can take some time to complete, they are worth doing for large tables that are used in a lot of analytic queries.

msg.data:
Major Compactions

Splice Machine stores its data in HBase HFiles. HBase is good at handling the creation of HFiles as needed; however, it’s important to be aware that HBase does perform asynchronous maintenance tasks to keep HFile working as efficiently as possible:

  • HBase kicks off Minor compactions as a minor HFiles housekeeping task.
  • HBase triggers Major compactions less frequently; these do much more housekeeping.

If you’ve just imported a lot of data (say 10M rows or so), it may be worth your while to manually trigger a major compaction using Splice Machine’s PERFORM_MAJOR_COMPACTION_ON_TABLE command. Click to run the next paragraph, which triggers a major compaction of your import_example table.

Though major compactions can take some time to complete, they are worth doing for large tables that are used in a lot of analytic queries.

paragraphs.text:
%splicemachine

call SYSCS_UTIL.SYSCS_PERFORM_MAJOR_COMPACTION_ON_TABLE('SPLICE','IMPORT_EXAMPLE')

%md ## Creating Primary Keys and Indexes Splice Machine, like other databases, supports the creation of primary keys and indexes; in Splice Machine: * the primary key becomes the key for the HBase table * an index is another HBase table whose key consists of the columns in the index * compound (multi-column) primary keys and indexes are supported

As with all databases that support indexes, an index improperly used can actually slow down a query. This is especially true with Splice Machine because it is a distributed system, which means that there may be a significant cost to looking up the non-indexed information in a query. This is why you may see Splice Machine intentionally NOT use an index when one is available.

Let's run through some quick examples. Click to run the next paragraph, which creates an example table; this should take less than a minute.

msg.data:
Creating Primary Keys and Indexes

Splice Machine, like other databases, supports the creation of primary keys and indexes; in Splice Machine:

  • the primary key becomes the key for the HBase table
  • an index is another HBase table whose key consists of the columns in the index
  • compound (multi-column) primary keys and indexes are supported

As with all databases that support indexes, an index improperly used can actually slow down a query. This is especially true with Splice Machine because it is a distributed system, which means that there may be a significant cost to looking up the non-indexed information in a query. This is why you may see Splice Machine intentionally NOT use an index when one is available.

Let’s run through some quick examples. Click to run the next paragraph, which creates an example table; this should take less than a minute.

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
schemaName	tableName	partition	rowsCollected	partitionSize	partitionCount	statsType	sampleFraction
SPLICE	INDEX_EXAMPLE	-All-	1310720	10485760	1	2	0.0

paragraphs.text:
%md
As you can see from the results of the above operation, we now have: * about 1.3 million rows of data * a primary key on `i` Click in the next paragraph to do lookups on `i`. You'll see that the primary key will find the record for us quickly:

msg.data:
As you can see from the results of the above operation, we now have:

  • about 1.3 million rows of data
  • a primary key on i

Click in the next paragraph to do lookups on i. You’ll see that the primary key will find the record for us quickly:

paragraphs.text:
%splicemachine

select * from index_example where i = 300000

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
That query should have come back almost immediately. But what happens if we query on j?

msg.data: That query should have come back almost immediately. But what happens if we query on j?

paragraphs.text:
%splicemachine

select * from index_example where j = 300000

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Adding an Index

You probably noticed this query required more time to complete; this is because there was no key to go straight to the record. Now, let's add an index on j:

msg.data:
Adding an Index

You probably noticed this query required more time to complete; this is because there was no key to go straight to the record. Now, let’s add an index on j:

paragraphs.text:
%splicemachine

create index ij on index_example (j)

%md
If you rerun the previous j query, it now runs quickly. This is because the optimizer considered both plan options available to it (with and without an index), found a lower cost for the plan using the index, and executed that plan. This is where `EXPLAIN` can be quite useful as well: you can discover if an index is being used or not. Click in the next paragraph to run the `explain`:

msg.data:
If you rerun the previous j query, it now runs quickly. This is because the optimizer considered both plan options available to it (with and without an index), found a lower cost for the plan using the index, and executed that plan.

This is where EXPLAIN can be quite useful as well: you can discover if an index is being used or not. Click in the next paragraph to run the explain:

paragraphs.text:
%splicemachine

explain select j from index_example where j = 300000

%md
### When an Index Doesn't Help

You can see that this performs an *IndexScan* (vs. a *TableScan*), and it tells you which index it uses, as well as the usual cost information, etc.

Let's get into a more complicated case where it is __not__ a good idea to use a particular index. In the next paragraph, we start with an `EXPLAIN` on our query:

msg.data:
When an Index Doesn’t Help

You can see that this performs an IndexScan (vs. a TableScan), and it tells you which index it uses, as well as the usual cost information, etc.

Let’s get into a more complicated case where it is not a good idea to use a particular index. In the next paragraph, we start with an EXPLAIN on our query:

paragraphs.text:
%splicemachine

explain select count(*) from
  (select j,i from index_example
     where j > 950000) a

msg.data:
Plan
Cursor(n=6,rows=1,updateMode=READ_ONLY (1),engine=Spark)
  ->  ScrollInsensitive(n=5,totalCost=6707.42,outputRows=1,outputHeapSize=0 B,partitions=1)
    ->  ProjectRestrict(n=4,totalCost=1419.578,outputRows=524288,outputHeapSize=0 B,partitions=1)
      ->  GroupBy(n=3,totalCost=1419.578,outputRows=524288,outputHeapSize=4 MB,partitions=1)
        ->  ProjectRestrict(n=2,totalCost=1419.578,outputRows=524288,outputHeapSize=4 MB,partitions=1)
          ->  TableScan[INDEX_EXAMPLE(1632)](n=1,totalCost=1419.578,scannedRows=1310720,outputRows=524288,outputHeapSize=4 MB,partitions=1,preds=[(J[0:2] > 950000)])

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Adding Hints

Note that the optimizer chose the plan that uses the actual table, NOT the index; why did it make this choice?

We can learn more about this by using a Splice Machine *hint* to force use of an index. We use an `index` hint in next paragraph:

msg.data:
Adding Hints

Note that the optimizer chose the plan that uses the actual table, NOT the index; why did it make this choice?

We can learn more about this by using a Splice Machine hint to force use of an index. We use an index hint in next paragraph:

paragraphs.text:
%splicemachine

explain select count(*) from
  (select j,i from index_example --splice-properties index=ij
     where j > 950000) a

msg.data:
Plan
Cursor(n=7,rows=1,updateMode=READ_ONLY (1),engine=Spark)
  ->  ScrollInsensitive(n=6,totalCost=2102993.101,outputRows=1,outputHeapSize=0 B,partitions=1)
    ->  ProjectRestrict(n=5,totalCost=2097701.26,outputRows=524288,outputHeapSize=0 B,partitions=1)
      ->  GroupBy(n=4,totalCost=2097701.26,outputRows=524288,outputHeapSize=4 MB,partitions=1)
        ->  ProjectRestrict(n=3,totalCost=2097701.26,outputRows=524288,outputHeapSize=4 MB,partitions=1)
          ->  IndexLookup(n=2,totalCost=2097701.26,outputRows=524288,outputHeapSize=4 MB,partitions=1)
            ->  IndexScan[IJ(1649)](n=1,totalCost=549.26,scannedRows=524288,outputRows=524288,outputHeapSize=4 MB,partitions=1,baseTable=INDEX_EXAMPLE(1632),preds=[(J[1:2] > 950000)])

paragraphs.text:
%md
You add a Splice Machine __hint__ to your queries by appending a specially formatted *comment*. These hints: * are always prefaced by `--splice-properties` * must always be placed at the end of a line * can be used either after a table name or after a `FROM` clause The *index hint* in the above example (`--splice-properties index=ij`) is an explicit instruction to the optimizer to use that named index now. And the results of using the index are evident in the generated plan, which now uses `IndexScan` instead of the `TableScan`. We can also see that the total cost (at the top of each plan) is much higher when using the index. Why is that? It's because the index only contains information for column `J`, and this query calls for information about column `I` as well. This means that we still have to get information from the base table for column I, and we have to do it *many* times. You can see this in the plan: there is a step, `IndexLookup`, that is part of the plan. You'll also see the cost jump up on that step, because for every row of where column J matches the criteria that we need to scan (and the optimizer estimates there are more then a million matches), we have to go back over to the base table to get the information about column `I`. In distributed architectures like Splice Machine, this can be a very expensive operation. If you want, you can run these these two queries by removing the `explains`; you'll noticed a significant performance difference between them.

If we change the > to = in the query, things change dramatically. Even though there is still an IndexLookup, it's only called once, so clearly use of the Index vs the Table is a better and faster plan. Try it and see!

When faced with situations where you have __many__ matching rows however, like our original query, you can address the issue by creating a compound index that includes both j and i in it:

msg.data:
You add a Splice Machine hint to your queries by appending a specially formatted comment. These hints:

  • are always prefaced by --splice-properties
  • must always be placed at the end of a line
  • can be used either after a table name or after a FROM clause

The index hint in the above example (--splice-properties index=ij) is an explicit instruction to the optimizer to use that named index now. And the results of using the index are evident in the generated plan, which now uses IndexScan instead of the TableScan. We can also see that the total cost (at the top of each plan) is much higher when using the index. Why is that?

It’s because the index only contains information for column J, and this query calls for information about column I as well. This means that we still have to get information from the base table for column I, and we have to do it many times. You can see this in the plan: there is a step, IndexLookup, that is part of the plan. You’ll also see the cost jump up on that step, because for every row of where column J matches the criteria that we need to scan (and the optimizer estimates there are more then a million matches), we have to go back over to the base table to get the information about column I. In distributed architectures like Splice Machine, this can be a very expensive operation.

If you want, you can run these these two queries by removing the explains; you’ll noticed a significant performance difference between them.

If we change the > to = in the query, things change dramatically. Even though there is still an IndexLookup, it's only called once, so clearly use of the Index vs the Table is a better and faster plan. Try it and see!

When faced with situations where you have many matching rows however, like our original query, you can address the issue by creating a compound index that includes both j and i in it:

paragraphs.text:
%splicemachine
create index iji on index_example (j, i)

%md
Running the original query will now choose this index, and run faster.

msg.data: Running the original query will now choose this index, and run faster.

paragraphs.text: %md ## Joining Tables Few queries are written without joins between tables. Shortly we will get into the join strategies Splice Machine employs, but first let's cover what it means to be on the *right* or *left* side of a join. To begin, we'll click to run the next paragraph, which creates some tables and then runs an `EXPLAIN` on a join on those tables:

msg.data:
Joining Tables

Few queries are written without joins between tables. Shortly we will get into the join strategies Splice Machine employs, but first let’s cover what it means to be on the right or left side of a join. To begin, we’ll click to run the next paragraph, which creates some tables and then runs an EXPLAIN on a join on those tables:

Plan
Cursor(n=9,rows=17,updateMode=READ_ONLY (1),engine=control)
  ->  ScrollInsensitive(n=8,totalCost=42.71,outputRows=17,outputHeapSize=76 B,partitions=1)
    ->  BroadcastJoin(n=7,totalCost=28.76,outputRows=17,outputHeapSize=76 B,partitions=1,preds=[(A.I[12:1] = D.I[12:4])])
      ->  TableScan[JOIN4(1728)](n=6,totalCost=4.04,scannedRows=20,outputRows=20,outputHeapSize=76 B,partitions=1)
      ->  BroadcastJoin(n=5,totalCost=20.52,outputRows=16,outputHeapSize=56 B,partitions=1,preds=[(A.I[8:1] = C.I[8:3])])
        ->  TableScan[JOIN3(1712)](n=4,totalCost=4.04,scannedRows=20,outputRows=20,outputHeapSize=56 B,partitions=1)
        ->  BroadcastJoin(n=3,totalCost=12.28,outputRows=16,outputHeapSize=36 B,partitions=1,preds=[(A.I[4:1] = B.I[4:2])])
          ->  TableScan[JOIN2(1696)](n=2,totalCost=4.04,scannedRows=20,outputRows=20,outputHeapSize=36 B,partitions=1)
          ->  TableScan[JOIN1(1680)](n=1,totalCost=4.04,scannedRows=20,outputRows=20,outputHeapSize=20 B,partitions=1)

paragraphs.text:
%md
For now, we'll ignore costs and join strategies and focus on the __order__ in which tables show up in the plan we just generated (with our `explain`). Again, we need to think through this *bottom-up:* when examining our plan: * The bottom-most table (`JOIN1`) is the *left-hand side* * The next up table (`JOIN2`) is the *right-hand side* * Each join needs a left-hand side and a right-hand side, so the bottom-most join will be joining tables `JOIN1` and `JOIN2`. * The __result__ of this bottom-most join becomes the __NEW__ *left-hand side*, and the table above it (in this case `JOIN3`) will be the *right-hand side* for the next join, and so on. It is important to know what table (or join result) represents the left-hand or right-hand side of the join.

msg.data:
For now, we’ll ignore costs and join strategies and focus on the order in which tables show up in the plan we just generated (with our explain). Again, we need to think through this bottom-up: when examining our plan:

  • The bottom-most table (JOIN1) is the left-hand side
  • The next up table (JOIN2) is the right-hand side
  • Each join needs a left-hand side and a right-hand side, so the bottom-most join will be joining tables JOIN1 and JOIN2.
  • The result of this bottom-most join becomes the NEW left-hand side, and the table above it (in this case JOIN3) will be the right-hand side for the next join, and so on.

It is important to know what table (or join result) represents the left-hand or right-hand side of the join.

paragraphs.text:
%md ### Join Strategies Databases employ different algorithms to efficiently perform a join, depending on the circumstances. Here are the join strategies Splice Machine employs:
Join Strategy Description
SortMerge Sorts the data being joined and performs a merge on the results
Merge Performs a merge, but is not valid unless the data is not pre-sorted (via primary key or index) on the join key
Broadcast Requires the right-hand-side table to be small (< 1 million rows), so that this table can be copied to all nodes for local joins on each node
NestedLoop The general-purpose join strategy
Each join strategy has its strengths and weaknesses, which are summarized here:
Join Strategy Strengths and Weaknesses
SortMerge

On queries processing a lot of data, when a Merge or Broadcast is not valid, SortMerge will be used.

It is slower than Merge and Broadcast, but can be used in more instances.
Merge

Generally the fastest query to process many rows of data on both the right and left side of the join.

However the data must be sorted on the join keys on both the right and left sides.
Broadcast

A very fast join algorithm as long as the *right-hand* table of the join has 1 million or fewer rows.
NestedLoop

The fastest join for *transaction-type* queries (i.e. keyed lookups with few rows on each side of the join).

If there are many rows on the right and/or left side, this query can be very slow.
When planning a query with joins, the optimizer will choose the join strategy with the lowest cost. Its choice however might again influence how you make your own changes (for example, add an index so that a SortMerge becomes a Merge). We will see more examples of this in the next Tutorial.

msg.data:
Join Strategies

Databases employ different algorithms to efficiently perform a join, depending on the circumstances. Here are the join strategies Splice Machine employs:

Join Strategy Description
SortMerge Sorts the data being joined and performs a merge on the results
Merge Performs a merge, but is not valid unless the data is not pre-sorted (via primary key or index) on the join key
Broadcast Requires the right-hand-side table to be small (< 1 million rows), so that this table can be copied to all nodes for local joins on each node
NestedLoop The general-purpose join strategy

Each join strategy has its strengths and weaknesses, which are summarized here:

Join Strategy Strengths and Weaknesses
SortMerge

On queries processing a lot of data, when a Merge or Broadcast is not valid, SortMerge will be used.

It is slower than Merge and Broadcast, but can be used in more instances.
Merge

Generally the fastest query to process many rows of data on both the right and left side of the join.

However the data must be sorted on the join keys on both the right and left sides.
Broadcast

A very fast join algorithm as long as the *right-hand* table of the join has 1 million or fewer rows.
NestedLoop

The fastest join for *transaction-type* queries (i.e. keyed lookups with few rows on each side of the join).

If there are many rows on the right and/or left side, this query can be very slow.

When planning a query with joins, the optimizer will choose the join strategy with the lowest cost. Its choice however might again influence how you make your own changes (for example, add an index so that a SortMerge becomes a Merge). We will see more examples of this in the next Tutorial.

paragraphs.text: %md ## Where to Go Next We'll get deeper into tuning queries in our next tutorial, Using the DB Console UI. Our documentation has more information about the strategies described here; these topics are particularly relevant: * The Tuning and Debugging section of our Developer's Guide * The Join Operations section of our SQL Reference Manual.

msg.data:
Where to Go Next

We’ll get deeper into tuning queries in our next tutorial, Using the DB Console UI.

Our documentation has more information about the strategies described here; these topics are particularly relevant:

  • The Tuning and Debugging section of our Developer's Guide
  • The Join Operations section of our SQL Reference Manual.
